#Text=CHAPTER X
#Text=A charming introduction to a hermit 's life !
#Text=Four weeks ' torture , tossing , and sickness !

#Text=Oh , these bleak winds and bitter northern skies , and impassable roads , and dilatory country surgeons ! And oh , this dearth of the human physiognomy ! and , worse than all , the terrible intimation of Kenneth that I need not expect to be out of doors till spring !
#Text=Mr. Heathcliff has just honoured me with a call .
#Text=About seven days ago he sent me a brace of grouse -- the last of the season .
#Text=Scoundrel !
#Text=He is not altogether guiltless in this illness of mine ; and that I had a great mind to tell him .
#Text=But , alas ! how could I offend a man who was charitable enough to sit at my bedside a good hour , and talk on some other subject than pills and draughts , blisters and leeches ?
#Text=This is quite an easy interval .
#Text=I am too weak to read ; yet I feel as if I could enjoy something interesting .

#Text=Why not have up Mrs. Dean to finish her tale ? I can recollect its chief incidents , as far as she had gone . Yes : I remember her hero had run off , and never been heard of for three years ; and the heroine was married .
#Text=I 'll ring : she 'll be delighted to find me capable of talking cheerfully .
#Text=Mrs. Dean came .
#Text='
#Text=It wants twenty minutes , sir , to taking the medicine , ' she commenced .
#Text=' Away , away with it ! ' I replied ; ' I desire to have -- '
#Text='
#Text=The doctor says you must drop the powders . '
#Text='
#Text=With all my heart !
#Text=Do n't interrupt me .
#Text=Come and take your seat here .
#Text=Keep your fingers from that bitter phalanx of vials .
#Text=Draw your knitting out of your pocket -- that will do -- now continue the history of Mr. Heathcliff , from where you left off , to the present day .

#Text=Did he finish his education on the Continent , and come back a gentleman ? or did he get a sizar 's place at college , or escape to America , and earn honours by drawing blood from his foster-country ?
#Text=or make a fortune more promptly on the English highways ? '
#Text='
#Text=He may have done a little in all these vocations , Mr. Lockwood ; but I could n't give my word for any .

#Text=I stated before that I did n't know how he gained his money ; neither am I aware of the means he took to raise his mind from the savage ignorance into which it was sunk : but , with your leave , I 'll proceed in my own fashion , if you think it will amuse and not weary you .
#Text=Are you feeling better this morning ? '
#Text=' Much . '
#Text=' That 's good news .
#Text='
#Text=I got Miss Catherine and myself to Thrushcross Grange ; and , to my agreeable disappointment , she behaved infinitely better than I dared to expect .
#Text=She seemed almost over-fond of Mr. Linton ; and even to his sister she showed plenty of affection .
#Text=They were both very attentive to her comfort , certainly .
#Text=It was not the thorn bending to the honeysuckles , but the honeysuckles embracing the thorn .
#Text=There were no mutual concessions : one stood erect , and the others yielded : and who can be ill-natured and bad-tempered when they encounter neither opposition nor indifference ?
#Text=I observed that Mr. Edgar had a deep-rooted fear of ruffling her humour .

#Text=He concealed it from her ; but if ever he heard me answer sharply , or saw any other servant grow cloudy at some imperious order of hers , he would show his trouble by a frown of displeasure that never darkened on his own account .
#Text=He many a time spoke sternly to me about my pertness ; and averred that the stab of a knife could not inflict a worse pang than he suffered at seeing his lady vexed .
#Text=Not to grieve a kind master , I learned to be less touchy ; and , for the space of half a year , the gunpowder lay as harmless as sand , because no fire came near to explode it .

#Text=Catherine had seasons of gloom and silence now and then : they were respected with sympathising silence by her husband , who ascribed them to an alteration in her constitution , produced by her perilous illness ; as she was never subject to depression of spirits before .
#Text=The return of sunshine was welcomed by answering sunshine from him .
#Text=I believe I may assert that they were really in possession of deep and growing happiness .
#Text=It ended .

#Text=Well , we must be for ourselves in the long run ; the mild and generous are only more justly selfish than the domineering ; and it ended when circumstances caused each to feel that the one 's interest was not the chief consideration in the other 's thoughts .
#Text=On a mellow evening in September , I was coming from the garden with a heavy basket of apples which I had been gathering .
#Text=It had got dusk , and the moon looked over the high wall of the court , causing undefined shadows to lurk in the corners of the numerous projecting portions of the building .

#Text=I set my burden on the house-steps by the kitchen-door , and lingered to rest , and drew in a few more breaths of the soft , sweet air ; my eyes were on the moon , and my back to the entrance , when I heard a voice behind me say , -- 'Nelly , is that you ? '
#Text=It was a deep voice , and foreign in tone ; yet there was something in the manner of pronouncing my name which made it sound familiar .
#Text=I turned about to discover who spoke , fearfully ; for the doors were shut , and I had seen nobody on approaching the steps .
#Text=Something stirred in the porch ; and , moving nearer , I distinguished a tall man dressed in dark clothes , with dark face and hair .
#Text=He leant against the side , and held his fingers on the latch as if intending to open for himself . ' Who can it be ? ' I thought . ' Mr. Earnshaw ?
#Text=Oh , no !
#Text=The voice has no resemblance to his . '
